Description: WILLAMETTE RESOURCES AND EDUCATIONAL NETWORK (WREN) SEEKS SUPPORT FROM THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT TO HIRE A 6-MONTH AMERICORPS INTERN THROUGH MT. ADAMS INSTITUTES PUBLIC LANDS STEWARDS PROGRAM. THIS INTERN WILL MAINTAIN AND BUILD PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT FOR MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AT THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. SPECIFICALLY, THIS INTERN WILL LEAD FIELD TRIPS IN THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS FOR K-12 STUDENTS, AND DEVELOP AN EVENT FOR AMERICAN WETLANDS MONTH, A POLLINATOR EVENT, AND A NATIONAL PUBLIC LANDS DAY EVENT. THE INTERN WILL ALSO MARKET AND PRESENT LESSONS AT LIBRARIES AND SUMMER CAMPS FOCUSING ON THE WORK DONE IN AND ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE OF THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS. ADDITIONALLY THE INTERN WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS BY WRITING WREN NEWSLETTER ARTICLES, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, AND OTHER INFORMATIVE MEDIA TO KEEP THE PUBLIC UP TO DATE AND ENGAGED WITH THE WORK BEING DONE IN THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS. THROUGH THE DESCRIBED EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES AND MARKETING EFFORTS IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE INTERN WILL REACH 1,500 COMBINED YOUTH AND ADULTS IN THE BETHEL, EUGENE, AND SPRINGFIELD COMMUNITIES BY THE TIME THE INTERNSHIP IS COMPLETE. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE FAMILIES, ADULTS, AND SCHOOL CHILDREN GRADES K-12 IN THE BETHEL, EUGENE, AND SPRINGFIELD OREGON COMMUNITIES. THE BLM IS ALSO AN INTENDED BENEFICIARY AS THESE EDUCATIONAL LESSONS AND MARKETING STRATEGIES WILL FURTHER BUILD PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT FOR MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES IN THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS. THIS INTERNSHIP PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE PAST 5 YEARS OF SUCCESS SHARED BY WREN AND THE BLM THROUGH SIMILAR INTERN PROJECTS, AND CONTINUE TO DEEPEN THE COMMUNITYS UNDERSTANDING OF THE WETLANDS.

FISHERIES BIOLOGIST INTERN. THE POSITION WILL PERFORM WORK RELATED TO WILDLIFE AND OR FISHERIES CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT, UTILIZING DEVELOPED PRINCIPLES AND METHODS. THE POSITION WILL BE REQUIRED TO GATHER QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DATA FOR BIOLOGICAL INVENTORIES RELATED TO THE MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC LANDS. THE SELECTED APPLICANT WILL ASSIST ROYAL GORGE FIELD OFFICE BIOLOGIST IN SEVERAL INVENTORY AND MONITORING PROJECTS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO RAPTOR NESTS INVENTORIES AND CLEARANCE, BAT ACOUSTIC MONITORING, SENSITIVE PLANTS MONITORING AND MEXICAN SPOTTED OWL ACOUSTIC AND CALL PLAYBACK SURVEYS.

2 INTERNS FOR THE 2023 FIELD SEASON TO ASSIST THE OHV TRAILS PROGRAM THAT WILL PROVIDE A EDUCATIONAL WORK EXPERIENCE TO LEARN ABOUT TRAVEL MANAGEMENT PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION, TRAIL MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE, VISITOR CONTACT AND MONITORING OF RECREATIONAL USE. THE INTERNSHIP WILL ALSO INCLUDE FACILITY MANAGEMENT AND MAINTENANCE THAT THE PUBLIC RELIES ON, AND THE INTERNSHIP WILL PROVIDE EXPERIENCE IN WORKING WITH MOTORIZED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE INTERNSHIP WOULD ALLOW THE INTERN TO LEARN ABOUT FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT CHALLENGES WITHIN HIGH USE AREAS SUCH AS THE NORTH SAND HILLS SRMA AND WOLFORD SRMA WHILE PROVIDING INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION TO PUBLIC VISITORS.

INTERNS WILL SERVE WITH EXPERIENCED BLM CREW LEADS AND SPECIALISTS TO MANAGE NOXIOUS WEED POPULATIONS IN RANGELAND ENVIRONMENTS. UNDER THE DIRECTION OF A BLM CREW LEAD AND SPECIALISTS, INTERNS WILL PERFORM ROUTINE AND RECURRING WEED MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING APPLYING HERBICIDES, IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS, ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS, COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS, AND SAFETY PLANS. APPROVED HERBICIDES WILL BE SPOT-SPRAYED FROM VEHICLES AND BACKPACK SPRAYERS. INTERNS WILL OPERATE, MAINTAIN, AND INVENTORY WEED MANAGEMENT EQUIPMENT (E.G., TOOLS, MONITORING MAPPING EQUIPMENT, HERBICIDE APPLICATORS). INTERNS WILL HELP ENSURE ALL ACTIVITIES COMPLY WITH EXISTING PROTOCOLS AND POLICIES AS THEY RELATE TO WEED MANAGEMENT. BLM WILL PROVIDETRAINING AND PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT. ONLY BLM CREW LEADS AND SPECIALISTS WITH A CURRENT APPLICATOR LICENSE WILL MIX HERBICIDES.

THE SOUTHERN NEVADA DISTRICT OFFICE HAS BEEN WORKING TOWARD THE RESTORATION OF KEY VEGETATION COMMUNITIES FOR WELL OVER A DECADE  THESE COMMUNITIES INCLUDE RIPARIAN HABITAT ADJACENT TO SPRINGS AND IN THE VIRGIN RIVER WATERSHED, AS WELL AS UPLAND HABITAT IN ACECS  THESE VEGETATION COMMUNITIES INCLUDE SOME OF THE LAST REMAINING NESTING HABITAT FOR THE ENDANGERED SOUTHWESTERN WILLOW FLYCATCHER AND AREAS HABITAT FOR THE THREATENED MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISE  YOUTH INTERNSHIPS HAVE BEEN AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT IN THE ON GOING EFFORT TO RESTORE THE ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY TO RIPARIAN AND UPLAND PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE BEEN SEVERELY DEGRADED BY INVASIVE PLANTS, UNREGULATED OHV ACTIVITY, OVERGRAZING AND OTHER DISTURBANCE AGENTS THE MAIN PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO RE ESTABLISH NATIVE PLANT DOMINANCE ON SITES THAT HAVE BEEN OVERCOME BY INVASIVE PLANTS AND OR HAVE BEEN DENUDED BY DISTURBANCE  THIS IS A LONG TERM EFFORT THAT MAY TAKE SEVERAL YEARS IN RIPARIAN AREAS, AND DECADES IN UPLAND DESERT AREAS  HOWEVER, ONCE THE TRAJECTORY TOWARD NATIVE SPECIES DOMINANCE IS SET, NATURAL RECOVERY CAN BE ACCELERATED THE INTERN WILL PRIMARILY BE RESPONSIBLE COORDINATING WORK AND LOGISTICS OF A CONSERVATION CREW WHICH WILL INCLUDE A VARIETY OF RESTORATION TASKS IN THE VIRGIN RIVER WATERSHED THE INTERN WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR MAPPING USING THE ARCGIS PLATFORM, RECORDING RESTORATION TECHNIQUES UTILIZED, QUANTIFYING VEGETATION REMOVED AND PLANTED, DATA ANALYSIS AND COLLECTION, AND ENSURING ACCURATE RECORDS

THE SOUTHERN NEVADA DISTRICT OFFICE HAS BEEN WORKING TOWARD THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF POPULATIONS OF THE THREATENED MOJOAVE DESERT TORTOISE SINCE ITS ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTING IN THE 1990S  A RECENT FOCUS OF THIS WORK INCLUDES RESCUING TORTOISES IN THE PATH OF DEVELOPMENT AND REARING THEM FOR RELEASE BACK INTO THE WILD AND MONITORING ECOSYSTEM CHARACTERISTICS THAT AFFECT TORTOISE POPULATIONS INCLUDING NESTING AND OCCURRENCE OF COMMON RAVENS WHICH ARE A KEY PREDATOR OF YOUNG TORTOISES ASSOCIATED WITH THE INTERN WILL PROVIDE HUSBANDRY FOR MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISES RESCUED FROM PROJECTS AND TEMPORARILY HOUSED AT THE BLM DESERT TORTOISE RESEARCH CENTER  DTRC , FORMALLY THE DESERT TORTOISE CONSERVATION CENTER  TORTOISE CENTER   HUSBANDRY INCLUDES PROVIDING FOOD AND WATER, HEALTH INSPECTIONS, TRANSPORTATION TO AND FROM VETERINARY CARE AS NEEDED, AND ADMINISTRATION OF MEDICATIONS PRESCRIBED BY VET FOR HOUSED ANIMALS AND INSPECTION OF FENCING AND MINOR REPAIRS TO FENCING AS NEEDED  MONITORING OF RAVENS WILL BE DONE BY DRIVING POWERLINE ROADS AND RECORDING NESTS AND TORTOISE REMAINS, COLLECTING SAMPLES AND DATA

THE SOUTHERN NEVADA DISTRICT OFFICE HAS BEEN WORKING TOWARD THE RESTORATION OF KEY VEGETATION COMMUNITIES FOR WELL OVER A DECADE  THESE COMMUNITIES INCLUDE RIPARIAN HABITAT ADJACENT TO SPRINGS AND IN THE VIRGIN RIVER WATERSHED, AS WELL AS UPLAND HABITAT IN ACECS  THESE VEGETATION COMMUNITIES INCLUDE SOME OF THE LAST REMAINING NESTING HABITAT FOR THE ENDANGERED SOUTHWESTERN WILLOW FLYCATCHER AND AREAS HABITAT FOR THE THREATENED MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISE  YOUTH CREWS HAVE BEEN AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT IN THE ON GOING EFFORT TO RESTORE THE ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY TO RIPARIAN AND UPLAND PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE BEEN SEVERELY DEGRADED BY INVASIVE PLANTS, UNREGULATED OHV ACTIVITY, OVERGRAZING AND OTHER DISTURBANCE AGENTS THE MAIN PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO RE ESTABLISH NATIVE PLANT DOMINANCE ON SITES THAT HAVE BEEN OVERCOME BY INVASIVE PLANTS AND OR HAVE BEEN DENUDED BY DISTURBANCE  THIS IS A LONG TERM EFFORT THAT MAY TAKE SEVERAL YEARS IN RIPARIAN AREAS, AND DECADES IN UPLAND DESERT AREAS  HOWEVER, ONCE THE TRAJECTORY TOWARD NATIVE SPECIES DOMINANCE IS SET, NATURAL RECOVERY CAN BE ACCELERATED YOUTH CREWS WILL PERFORM A VARIETY OF RESTORATION TASKS, INCLUDING  COLLECTING NATIVE SEED, TRANSPORTING SEEDLINGS FROM THE GREENHOUSE TO RESTORATION SITES, PLANTING SEEDLINGS, INSTALLING TEMPORARY FENCING, CAGES, AND PLASTIC PLANT TUBES TO PROTECT SEEDLINGS FROM HERBIVORY, USING HAND TOOLS TO DECOMPACT SOIL, DIG HOLES FOR PLANTING OR CREATING VERTICAL MULCH, AND REMOVING INVASIVE TAMARISK TREES USING CHAIN SAWS

THE SOUTHERN NEVADA DISTRICT OFFICE HAS ESTABLISHED THE PROTECTION OF GOLD BUTTE S CULTURAL HERITAGE AS A PRIORITY PROJECT FOR THE GOLD BUTTE NATIONAL MONUMENT  PROTECTION MEASURES NECESSARY ARE DIRECTED IN THE SOUTHERN NEVADA PUBLIC LANDS MANAGEMENT ACT  SNPLMA  PROJECT BL85, PROTECTING GOLD BUTTE S CULTURAL HERITAGE  THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON THREE CULTURAL COMPLEXES IN THE GOLD BUTTE AREA THAT ARE WELL KNOWN AND RECEIVE HEAVY VISITATION BY THE PUBLIC  THE THREE COMPLEXES INCLUDE  WHITNEY POCKET, AN AREA CURRENTLY DESIGNATED AS AN ACEC CONTAINING ONE HISTORIC CIVILIAN CONSERVATION CORPS CAMP AND ONE PREHISTORIC ROCK SHELTER AND ROASTING PIT SITE  FALLING MAN ROCK WRITING COMPLEX  AND KIRK S GROTTO SITE COMPLEX, A SLOT CANYON CONTAINING A NUMBER OF PETROGLYPH PANELS THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO RESTORE TRAILS AND ROUTES PREVIOUSLY CLOSED THROUGH TRAVEL MANAGEMENT PLANNING THAT ACCESS THREE CULTURAL COMPLEXES AND LEAD TO THE DEGRADATION OF THE SITES  THIS IS A LONG TERM EFFORT THAT MAY TAKE SEVERAL YEARS TO RESTORE  FULL RESTORATION MAY NOT BE COMPLETED FOR DECADES FOLLOWING THE RESEEDING OF THESE ROUTES AND TRAILS YOUTH CREWS WILL PERFORM A VARIETY OF RESTORATION TASKS, INCLUDING COLLECTING NATIVE SEED, TRANSPORTING SEEDLINGS FROM THE GREENHOUSE TO RESTORATION SITES, PLANTING SEEDLINGS, INSTALLING TEMPORARY FENCING, AND BARRIERS TO PROTECT RESTORATION AREAS, USING HAND TOOLS TO DECOMPACT SOIL, DIG HOLES FOR PLANTING OR CREATING VERTICAL MULCH, INSTALLING SIGNAGE AND REMOVING REMNANTS FROM ESTABLISHED CAMPSITES

THE SOUTHERN NEVADA DISTRICT OFFICE HAS ESTABLISHED THE PROTECTION OF GOLD BUTTE S CULTURAL HERITAGE AS A PRIORITY PROJECT FOR THE GOLD BUTTE NATIONAL MONUMENT  PROTECTION MEASURES NECESSARY ARE DIRECTED IN THE SOUTHERN NEVADA PUBLIC LANDS MANAGEMENT ACT  SNPLMA  PROJECT BL85, PROTECTING GOLD BUTTE S CULTURAL HERITAGE  THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON THREE CULTURAL COMPLEXES IN THE GOLD BUTTE AREA THAT ARE WELL KNOWN AND RECEIVE HEAVY VISITATION BY THE PUBLIC  THE THREE COMPLEXES INCLUDE  WHITNEY POCKET, AN AREA CURRENTLY DESIGNATED AS AN ACEC CONTAINING ONE HISTORIC CIVILIAN CONSERVATION CORPS CAMP AND ONE PREHISTORIC ROCK SHELTER AND ROASTING PIT SITE  FALLING MAN ROCK WRITING COMPLEX  AND KIRK S GROTTO SITE COMPLEX, A SLOT CANYON CONTAINING A NUMBER OF PETROGLYPH PANELS THE PROJECT PROMOTES CONNECTIVITY BY LINKING PEOPLE WITH NATURE AND IMPROVING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AT THREE CULTURAL RESOURCE COMPLEXES THROUGH EDUCATION, INTERPRETATION, AND OUTREACH WHILE PROTECTING CULTURAL RESOURCES EVEN WITH INCREASED REACREATION USE  IT WILL SHOWCASE THE DIVERSE CULTURAL HERITAGE THROUGH PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATIONAL ELEMENTS INCLUDING TRIBAL PARTICIPATION, DEVELOPMENT OF INTERPRETIVE SIGNS, YOUTH INITIATIVES AND SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENCT DEVELOPMENT INTERNS WILL DEVELOP INFORMATION AND INTERPRETIVE KIOSKS TO FOR CULTURAL RESOURCE COMPLEXES THAT AID IN THE CONNECTIVY OF THE NATIVE AMERICAN HERITAGE TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND VISITING PUBLIC  UTILIZING TRIBAL CONSULTATION AND COORDINATION WITH BLM, INTERPRETIVE KIOSKS WILL PROVIDE A CRITICAL LINK BETWEEN CURRENT AND TRADITIONAL USES OF THE LANDS THEY ARE DESIGNED TO HIGHLIGHT  KIOSKS WILL BE DESIGNED AND PRODUCED UTILIZING CURRENT AVAILABLE COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY AND RESOURCES, WHILE IDENTIFYING A MEANS TO ENSURE INTERNATIONAL UNDERSTANDING OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED

THE CARSON CITY DISTRICT OF THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  MANAGES 4 8 MILLION ACRES OF PUBLIC LANDS IN WESTERN NEVADA AND EASTERN CALIFORNIA, HAVING A VARIED LANDSCAPE MADE UP OF  CONIFEROUS FORESTS OF THE EASTERN SIERRA NEVADA  PINYON JUNIPER WOODLANDS SAGEBRUSH DOMINATED AREAS  AND SALT DESERT SHRUB DOMINATED AREAS  LOCAL ECOSYSTEMS INCLUDE  HIGH ALTITUDE MONTANE, SAND DUNES, ALKALI PLAYAS, MEADOWS, AND AREAS RECOVERING FROM WILDFIRE THE BLM CARSON CITY DISTRICT IS EQUIPPED TO MENTOR AND INTRODUCE YOUTH TO CAREERS IN THE BLM BY PROVIDING A VARIED AND MEANING FULL RANGE OF OPPORTUNITIES WHILE ACCOMPLISHING DISTRICT PRIORITIES IN MULTIPLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT THAT BENEFIT PUBLIC LANDS  BLM SPECIALISTS IN BOTANY, RANGE, AND EMERGENCY STABILIZATION AND REHABILITATION WILL GUIDE THE YOUTH CREWS IN COMPLETING THE WORK, AS WELL AS PROVIDING INSIGHTS INTO RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND CAREER OPPORTUNITIES

THE MAIN PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO RE ESTABLISH NATIVE PLANT DOMINANCE ON SITES THAT HAVE BEEN OVERCOME BY INVASIVE PLANTS AND OR HAVE BEEN DENUDED BY DISTURBANCE  THIS IS A LONG TERM EFFORT THAT MAY TAKE SEVERAL YEARS IN RIPARIAN AREAS, AND DECADES IN UPLAND DESERT AREAS  HOWEVER, ONCE THE TRAJECTORY TOWARD NATIVE SPECIES DOMINANCE IS SET, NATURAL RECOVERY CAN BE ACCELERATED YOUTH CREWS WILL PERFORM A VARIETY OF RESTORATION TASKS, INCLUDING  COLLECTING NATIVE SEED, TRANSPORTING SEEDLINGS FROM THE GREENHOUSE TO RESTORATION SITES, PLANTING SEEDLINGS, INSTALLING TEMPORARY FENCING, CAGES, AND PLASTIC PLANT TUBES TO PROTECT SEEDLINGS FROM HERBIVORY, USING HAND TOOLS TO DECOMPACT SOIL, DIG HOLES FOR PLANTING OR CREATING VERTICAL MULCH, AND REMOVING INVASIVE TAMARISK TREES USING CHAIN SAWS

AMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE  ACE  IS A NATIONAL LEADER IN RECRUITING, COORDINATING, AND TRAINING CONSERVATION VOLUNTEERS TO UNDERTAKE PRACTICAL ENVIRONMENTAL PRACTICAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECTS WITH US LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, INCLUDING THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, THE US FOREST SERVICE, THE FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND OTHER PUBLIC, NON PROFIT, OR PRIVATE LAND STEWARDS  ACE PROGRAMS PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH, YOUNG ADULTS, AND EMERGING PROFESSIONALS OF ALL BACKGROUNDS TO GAIN TANGIBLE, PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCES THROUGH MEANINGFUL, HANDS ON CONSERVATION PROJECTS  ACE HAS BEEN A PROUD PARTNER OF THE BLM SINCE OUR FOUNDING ALMOST TWENTY YEARS AGO ACE IS WELL QUALIFIED TO RECRUIT AND ENGAGE HIGH QUALITY CANDIDATES TO SUPPORT THE BLM  IN THE REGION, ACE HAS CURRENT PARTNERSHIPS WITH BLM NEVADA IN WINNEMUCCA DISTRICT OFFICE AND CARSON CITY DISTRICT OFFICE WITH MULTIPLE STATE, DISTRICT, AND FIELD OFFICES IN CALIFORNIA, UTAH, AND OREGON ACE S EPIC BLM DIVISION WILL RECRUIT, TRAIN AND FIELD TWO 20 WEEK INDIVIDUAL PLACEMENT MEMBERS PER YEAR IN YEARS ONE THROUGH FOUR, TO PROVIDE MEMBERS WITH AN ADEQUATE LIVING ALLOWANCE AND MEET THE FUNDING REQUIREMENTS MEMBERS IN YEAR FIVE WILL SERVE FOR 15 WEEKS  ACE MEMBERS WILL SUPPORT THE BLM NV, WINNEMUCCA DISTRICT OFFICE IN PROPER MANAGEMENT OF LIMITED WATER RESOURCES THROUGH INVENTORY AND MONITORING OF SPRINGS, STREAMS, AND RIPARIAN AREAS  ACE MEMBERS WILL ASSIST WITH COMPLETING MULTIPLE INDICATOR MONITORING  MIM  SURVEYS ON STREAM CHANNELS AND STREAMSIDE VEGETATION ON SELECT SITES THROUGHOUT THE DISTRICT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RECRUIT AND PLACE SEVEN INTERNS WITH BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT OFFICES TO ASSIST IN NATURAL RESOURCES, ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, AND GIS APPLICATIONS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS TO GAIN EXPERIENCE, LEARN ABOUT PUBLIC LANDS, FURTHER THEIR UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, AND PIQUE THEIR INTEREST IN FUTURE CAREERS IN PUBLIC SERVICE THROUGH THE GEM CORPS WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM IN ACCORDANCE WITH PUBLIC LAND CORPS GUIDLINES  DURING THIS PROJECT, INTERNS WILL PARTICIPATE IN ACTIVITIES WITH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES  REDUCTION OF WILDFIRE RISK TO COMMUNITIES, WATERSHEDS, AND OTHER PUBLIC LAND ECOSYSTEMS    PRODUCTION OF MATERIALS AND PROGRAMS ON NATURAL, CULTURAL, AND OR PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES, COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, AND INTERPRETATION OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES    MONITORING RIPARIAN AREA VEGETATION AND HYDROLOGICAL FUNCTIONS, COLLECTING SOIL AND STREAM DATA, TIMBER STAND IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT AND OVERALL FOREST HEALTH    HABITAT RESTORATION AND WILDLIFE PROTECTION, INCLUDING REDUCTION OF INVASIVE SPECIES, TREE PLANTING, FENCE REMOVAL INSTALLATION, RIPARIAN AREA RESTORATION, ETC   DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PLANS OR EDUCATIONAL AND INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS FOR VISITORS    PERFORMANCE OF STUDIES SUCH AS RESOURCE INVENTORIES, HISTORIC OR ARCHIVAL RESEARCH, ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATION OR STABILIZATION, ORAL HISTORIES, HISTORIC PRESERVATION, HABITAT SURVEYS, ETC   PERFORMANCE OF IN HOUSE PROJECTS, SUCH AS SCIENCE, POLICY, OR PROGRAM INTERNSHIPS, WITH A CLEAR BENEFIT FOR NATURAL OR CULTURAL RESOURCES  IN HOUSE PROJECTS TO INCLUDE A FIELD COMPONENT OF AT LEAST 120 HOURS

MONTANA CONSERVATION CORPS CREWS HAVE SPENT MULTIPLE YEARS WORKING TO SUPPORT THE ENOS CREEK PROJECT  IN THE WIND RIVER BIGHORN BASIN DISTRICT. THE ENOS CREEK AREA COVERS APPROXIMATELY 1000 ACRES OF  JUNIPER HABITAT THAT HAS ENCROACHED INTO THE RIPARIAN AREA AND FIRST-TIER FLOOD PLAIN SAGE BRUSH HABITAT. THE  PRESENCE OF THE JUNIPER HAS GREATLY SLOWED WATER FLOW IN THE CREEK BEDS, DRASTICALLY AFFECTING WILDLIFE  HABITAT IN THE AREA. THE REMOVAL OF CONIFER TREES WILL HELP TO REDUCE THE COMPETITION AND OPEN UP SPACE AND  PROVIDE MORE RESOURCES FOR MORE VALUABLE SPECIES LIKE ASPENS. ASPENS PLAY A VITAL ROLE IN LARGE UNGULATES  DIET DURING HARD WINTERS AS ELK, MOOSE AND MULE DEER WILL EAT THE OUTER BARK AND CAMBIUM LAYER OF THE  TREES TO SUSTAIN THEMSELVES WHILE MOVING BETWEEN WINTER RANGES.  THE PRIMARY PROJECT SCOPE HAS AND WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS ON REDUCING HAZARDOUS FUELS, IMPROVING RIPARIAN  HABITAT AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION, AND IMPROVING CONDITIONS OF SAGE GROUSE HABITAT. THE MCC CREW WOULD  WORK WITH THE BLM TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY LOCATIONS TO ELIMINATE THE JUNIPER REGROWTH THAT HAS SPROUTED UP  SINCE THE ORIGINAL MASTICATION OF TREES FIRST OCCURRED. THE CREW WILL WORK WITH LOPPERS, HANDSAWS AND  CHAINSAWS TO IDENTIFY AND REMOVE THE RE-SPROUTS. IN SOME CASES, DEBRIS WILL BE SCATTERED BUT IN DESIGNATED  AREAS THE CREW WILL PILE SLASH FOR LATER BURNING TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF HAZARDOUS FUELS ON THE FOREST FLOOR. THE TARGET FOR THE 2022 SEASON WILL BE TO ADDRESS100-200 ACRES OF HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION, VEGETATION  MANAGEMENT AND WILDLIFE  LED BY TWO CREW LEADERS WHO SPENT LAST SUMMER WORKING ON THE ENOS CREEK PROJECT, THE CREW WILL SPEND  11 WEEKS OPERATING ON A 9 ON 5 OFF SCHEDULE, GENERALLY CAMPING ON SITE, TO ACCOMPLISH THESE PROJECT TASKS  WITH THE GUIDANCE AND SUPPORT OF BLM PARTNERSHIP. IN ADDITION TO PROJECT WORK, THE CREW WILL GAIN  VALUABLE WORK EXPERIENCE LEARNING MORE ABOUT FIRE ECOLOGY, WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, AND NATURAL RESOURCE  MANAGEMENT. THE MCC CREW WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH BLM STAFF TO FOLLOW PROJECT SPECIFICATIONS AND  PROVIDE DOCUMENTATION AND DATA OF ALL PROJECT ACCOMPLISHMENTS.

THE MISSION OF THE WASHINGTON CONSERVATION CORPS (WCC) IS TO CONSERVE, REHABILITATE AND ENHANCE THE STATE'S NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES WHILE PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND MEANINGFUL SERVICE EXPERIENCES FOR YOUNG ADULTS AND MILITARY VETERANS. WCC IS A STATE PROGRAM THAT WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE LEGISLATURE IN 1983 AND IS HOUSED WITHIN THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY.WCC FIELD CREWS SERVE DIRECTLY WITH PARTNERING ORGANIZATIONS TO COMPLETE PROJECTS WHICH PHYSICALLY IMPROVE THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT OR EXPAND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC. THIS PROJECT WOULD ALLOW WCC CREWS TO PERFORM VITAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE THROUGH THE BLM SPOKANE DISTRICT, INCLUDING THE WENATCHEE FIELD OFFICE. THIS FUNDING WOULD PROVIDE YOUNG ADULTS AND MILITARY VETERANS WITH A MEANINGFUL SERVICE EXPERIENCE WHERE THEY WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, RESTORATION STRATEGIES, AND OTHER VALUABLE JOB SKILLS.AS A YOUTH CORPS PROGRAM, WCC IS COMMITTED TO DEVELOPING AND TRAINING YOUNG ADULTS AND MILITARY VETERANS TO WORK IN THE NATURAL RESOURCES, ENVIRONMENTAL RESTORATION AND RECREATION ENHANCEMENT FIELDS. BLM'S SUPPORT FOR THIS REQUEST WILL ENABLE WCC TO TRAIN THESE YOUNG ADULTS WHILE ALSO COMPLETING RESTORATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS THAT WILL DEVELOP FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, MITIGATE THE RISK OF NATURAL DISASTERS, AND IMPROVE WATERSHEDS.

THE MISSION OF THE WASHINGTON CONSERVATION CORPS (WCC) IS TO CONSERVE, REHABILITATE AND ENHANCE THE STATE'S NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES WHILE PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND MEANINGFUL SERVICE EXPERIENCES FOR YOUNG ADULTS AND MILITARY VETERANS. WCC WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE STATE LEGISLATURE IN 1983 AND IS HOUSED WITHIN THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY.WCC FIELD CREWS SERVE DIRECTLY WITH PARTNERING ORGANIZATIONS TO COMPLETE PROJECTS WHICH PHYSICALLY IMPROVE THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT OR EXPAND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC. THIS PROJECT WOULD ALLOW WCC CREWS TO PERFORM VITAL RECREATION MANAGEMENT SUPPORT ACTIVITIES AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGH THE BLM SPOKANE DISTRICT, INCLUDING THE WENATCHEE FIELD OFFICE. THIS FUNDING WOULD PROVIDE YOUNG ADULTS AND MILITARY VETERANS WITH A MEANINGFUL SERVICE EXPERIENCE WHERE THEY WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, RECREATION ENHANCEMENT STRATEGIES, AND OTHER VALUABLE JOB SKILLS.AS A YOUTH CORPS PROGRAM, WCC IS COMMITTED TO DEVELOPING AND TRAINING YOUNG ADULTS AND MILITARY VETERANS TO WORK IN THE NATURAL RESOURCES, ENVIRONMENTAL RESTORATION AND RECREATION ENHANCEMENT FIELDS. BLM'S SUPPORT FOR THIS REQUEST WILL ENABLE WCC TO TRAIN THESE YOUNG ADULTS WHILE ALSO COMPLETING RECREATION ENHANCEMENT AND ENVIRONMENTAL ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS THAT WILL DEVELOP IMPROVE RECREATION INFRASTRUCTURE AND ENGAGE IN ECOLOGICAL, LIVESTOCK GRAZING AND POST-WILDFIRE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES.

THIS PROJECT HAS TWO MAIN COMPONENTS: 1) ENGAGE 500 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WITH CONSERVATION CURRICULUM IN SCIENCE
CLASSROOMS IN CONCERT WITH ON-THE-GROUND PARTICIPATION IN FIELD TRIPS AND MONITORING PROJECTS; 2) CONDUCT SIX SURVEYS FOR YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO (A FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES) ALONG APPROXIMATELY 9 MILES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT IN THE AGUA FRIA WATERSHED. AUDUBON BIOLOGISTS WILL PROVIDE AND PRESENT CURRICULUM TO THE HIGH SCHOOL CLASSROOMS, AND LEAD STUDENTS ON FIELD TRIPS TO THE RIO SALADO AUDUBON CENTER AND BLM PUBLIC LANDS ON THE AGUA FRIA NATIONAL MONUMENT. AUDUBON BIOLOGIST WILL ALSO LEAD INTERNS AND VOLUNTEERS IN YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO SURVEYS ON BLM PUBLIC LANDS WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF THE HASSAYAMPA FIELD OFFICE. THIS PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF A TEN-YEAR PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN AUDUBON AND BLM IN ENGAGING YOUTH AND CARRYING OUT YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO MONITORING.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO REMOVE VEGETATION AND MINIMIZE EFFECTS OF EROSION ON TRAILS WITHIN THE GRAND CANYON-PARASHANT NATIONAL MONUMENT THAT CURRENTLY NEED REGULAR AND ROUTINE MAINTENANCE TO FACILITATE ACCESS FOR VISITORS. THE PROJECT ALSO INCREASES AMERICAN'S WITH DISABILITIES ACT (ADA) ACCESS AT TRAILHEADS AND NEAR KIOSK AND WAYSIDE SIGNAGE. IN ADDITION TO TRAIL AND TRAILHEAD IMPROVEMENTS, THIS PROJECT IMPROVES SAFETY MESSAGING AND EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH TO SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES IN THE SOUTHERN UTAH, NORTHERN ARIZONA, AND SOUTHERN NEVADA REGION.

THE LAKE HAVASU FIELD OFFICE (LHFO), PROPOSES TO PROVIDE EDUCATION, TRAINING AND MENTORING AND CAREER DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR AMERICAN YOUTH VIA THE LAKE HAVASU TRAILS IMPROVEMENT PROJECT. PARTICIPATING FIELD CREWS LEARN OF THE BLM'S MULTIPLE USE MISSION AND THE DAILY OPERATIONAL NEEDS OF A ROBUST RECREATION PROGRAM; CONSERVATION RELATED KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL SETS THAT THE CREW MEMBERS CAN TAKE WITH THEM AS THEY WORK TOWARDS THEIR RESPECTIVE CAREERS. THE PROGRAM WILL EMPLOY A FIELD CREW OF SIX TO EIGHT INDIVIDUALS TO ASSIST WITH ENSURING PUBLIC LANDS ARE CLEAN AND SAFE BY INSTALLING DIRECTIONAL TRAIL SIGNAGE, RESOURCE PROTECTION SIGNAGE, REPAIRING EXISTING SIGNAGE, PICKING UP TRASH, AND COLLECTING DATA TO CREATE A SIGN INVENTORY WITHIN MOTORIZED AND NON-MOTORIZED TRAILS IN THE LAKE HAVASU FIELD OFFICE. THE CREW IS EXPECTED TO TRACK ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND SIGN LOCATIONS AND UPDATE RESPECTIVE DATABASES AND FIELD OFFICE STAFF.
